item.title: Ideology cloaks power
item.description: Superficially, the means by which power conceals itself is through stories. Its needs narratives ‚Äî mainly about those who appear powerful ‚Äî to create political and social dramas that distract us from thinking about deep power. But more fundamentally still, power depends on ideology. Ideology cloaks power ‚Äì in a real sense, it is power ‚Äî because it is the source of power‚Äôs invisibility.

item.title: Power exists only so long as we consent
item.description: Power is the structure of the thoughts we think we control, a framework for the ideologies we think we voted for, the values we think we choose to treasure, the horizon of imaginations we think we created. Power exists only so long as we consent to it through our blind obedience.

item.title: Power is both structural and ideological
item.description: Power always has an ideological shape and¬†physical structures. It has both faces. It existed before capitalism, and will exist after it (if capitalism doesn‚Äôt kill us first). Human history has consisted of power consolidating and regenerating itself in new form over and over again ‚Äî like the eponymous hero of the long-running British TV sci-fi series Doctor Who ‚Äî as different groups have learnt how to harness it, usurp it and put it to self-interested use.

item.title: Nice guy fascism is still fascism
item.description: Funny how ‚Äúchanging the system from within‚Äù produces the same results as not even trying to change it at all. I call Obama‚Äôs particular brand of establishment sycophancy Nice Guy Fascism. It‚Äôs just like regular fascism, enabling the brutal dominion of a few depraved and bloodthirsty tyrants, except you get to look like a nice guy while you‚Äôre participating in it.

item.title: The most hideous ideologies are the ones we believe without realizing it
item.description: Hey! Here‚Äôs a thought! Do not yearn for the authoritarian school of social change! Do not force your ideas on anyone else! üíÄ I love people, but a lot of them‚Äîmaybe most?‚Äîyearn for their side to acquire absolute power. They seem to believe in the authoritarian school of social change: the only way to create a better world is for a strong central actor to force it on everybody else.

item.title: US exceptionalism is abusive narcissism
item.description: Exceptionalism has come to represent superiority in the minds and hearts of Americans, and belief in their economic, military and ideological supremacy is what has motivated successive US governments to shape the world in their ‚Äúsuperior‚Äù image with no regard for the destruction left in the wake of their exceptional hegemony.

item.title: Is fear of groupthink another pursuit of purity?
item.description: Is ridding yourself of all ‚Äúgroupthink‚Äù another pursuit of purity? Does the quest for purity only happen within the groupthink/ideology? Are there elements of ‚Äúgroupthink‚Äù that are merely the human traits as a communal species? Like censorship, there has never been some ideal state without it, only existing to various healthy or toxic degrees?

item.title: Forests disprove survival of the fittest
item.description: In a forest, well-being depends on community and diversity. It‚Äôs not a race to the top for dominance, but a web of interdependencies, that depends on even the supposedly ‚Äúweakest‚Äù trees for survival. It‚Äôs not survival of the fittest‚Äîtheir well-being depends on community. When supposedly feeble trees disappear, the others lose as well.

item.title: Institutional betrayal
item.description: Institutional betrayal is when an institution causes harm (by action or inaction) to anyone who trusts or depends on them. Red flags include strict membership requirements (the military, elite sports), prestige or power differentials (caregivers v. patients, clergy v. parishioners), and rigid priorities, like extreme efforts to protect the reputation of the organization.

item.title: Don‚Äôt pledge allegiance to any one ideology
item.description: Make a patchwork quilt! That‚Äôs so much more fun, effective, and reliable than devoting yourself to any one ideology. Ideology ‚Üí purity ‚Üí supremacy happens all the time. Or at best, you get tangled up in labels and abstractions, and the arguments thereof. The closest ideologies to my own values are an overlapping hodgepodge of taoism, anarchism, and indigenous animism, with a lil‚Äô sprinkling of socialism, etc.

item.title: Fascism can‚Äôt survive long term
item.description: How‚Äôs this for a shower thought: fascism keeps arising because fascism keeps getting defeated. It can‚Äôt survive long-term because it enforces so much conformity that it collapses. item.title: Power doesn‚Äôt need facts or evidence, just narrative and ideology
item.description: Power doesn‚Äôt need facts or evidence, even when its claims are self-evidently disruptive to the democratic process. It exists chiefly in the realm of narrative and ideology. This is a story, just like Corbyn‚Äôs ‚Äúantisemitism crisis‚Äù, that is made true simply through repetition. Because power is power, its narratives can defy the most elementary rules of logic.
